This definitely sounds like a simple difference in terminology to me.
Mitch=
ell equates the first layer of neurons with the input layer,
while Philip m=
eans something like the "zeroeth" layer with input
layer.

Some other peopl=
e would talk about layers as layers of weighted
connections, and the first =
layer would for them refer to the
connections between the input and the hid=
den neurons. The word "layer"
is terribly ambiguous, and only becomes more =
ambiguous when you try to
merge neural networks with something like the sub=
sumption
architecture, where layer means something completely different.

T=
hat being said, it should definitely be possible to start without any
conne=
ctions from the inputs, or any connections at all really. Modular
NEAT star=
ted with just one connection per module. I am myself at the
moment trying t=
o evolve simulated car controllers with very high
dimensional (visual) inpu=
t, and (although I am not using NEAT per se)
starting with an empty network=
 seems to be a more promising avenue
than starting with all inputs connecte=
d.

Julian

nnections, you mean connections

se don't have weights, they serve only to
>  > pass the input
>  > values t=
o the input neurons. 
>  <snip>
>  
>  Whoa!  In my experience most ANNs ha=
ve weights here,
>  lots of them.  It's often the case that the majority
> =
 of the weights are between the inputs and the first
>  layer of neurons.
>=

to read other people's responses to
